clinical_study.brief_title: Vitamin E Supplementation in Burned Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Vitamin E Supplementation in Burned Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

brief_summary.textblock: A dietary antioxidant, alpha-tocopherol, will be used to potentially attenuate Vitamin E short- and long-term losses in plasma and adipose, reverse the oxidative stress of burn injury and, in the process, decrease the secondary consequences of burn injury, including lung injury and impaired wound healing. This may improve the quality of life of the burn patient by preventing pathophysiology that may result from oxidative stress and may reduce hospital stay. Our research will lay the foundation for the future development of effective, safe, and economic therapeutic interventions to treat burn injury-associated metabolic abnormalities. Also, it will provide the basis for the development of supplemental regulations and pharmacotherapy to treat burn patients with vitamin E. The risks are very reasonable in relation to the anticipated benefits to our subjects because a) vitamin E is a simple vitamin that is abundant and approved for clinical use, and b) the subjects will be monitored consistently for the minimal increased tendency to bleed.

primary_outcome.description: Plasma measurements of alpha- and gamma-tocopherol as an indicator of antioxidant status

secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of pulmonary function by measuring variables such as functional vital capacity of the lungs and volume ventilation in an effort-dependent exam
Assessment of strength and cardiopulmonary function through use of exercise
Assessment of variables of the wound such as redness and scar height

secondary_outcome.measure: Plasma and Urine Malondialdehyde, Isoprostanes, Vitamin E Metabolites
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of antioxidant and oxidant status in plasma (short-term)
Assessment of antioxidant and oxidant status in adipose (long-term)

arm_group.description: Vitamin E is administered from Days 1-15 after the initial excision surgery after admission.
Vitamin E is administered from Days 16-30 after the initial excision surgery after admission.

intervention.description: 1200 IU dl-alpha tocopheryl acetate after the initial excision surgery after admission (days 1-15 or days 16-30)
